Myra was a member of @NSWLabor for more than 30 yrs, holding roles on committees + as Senior VP of the Darling Harbour Branch. She was a lifelong campaigner - fighting to save Millers Point Post Office, protect the heritage of our city, + advocating for more social housing.

I'd known Myra for yrs as an advocate + Labor member. She was the sort of person that made a suburb into a community. The heart of Millers Point for over 50 yrs, she was a helping hand to neighbours, the first to volunteer to cook a meal, or to bake scones for the charity drive.

Vale Myra Demetriou. Many knew Myra as the face of the Save Our Sirius campaign - the last remaining resident in the social housing in Millers Point after the NSW government sold it off. Legally blind, living on her own, standing up for what was right. Unstoppable. https://t.co/8oxdU880hE

Prosperity - educating Australians for their dream job. A university system designed to underpin job creation, productivity and our national prosperity. And where the
benefits of university research are used to create Australian jobs and economic growth.

Sustainability - where good levels of government investment in higher education can be sustained for decades. And where there’s a strong international education offering that both adds to the student experience and our national export income.

Certainty - giving students, unis + businesses the certainty to make long-term plans. Student fee levels that are reasonable + stable. Certainty of funding, eg legislated funding cycles that go beyond elections, that would allow unis to hire more permanent staff.

Quality - a high quality university system, centred around the needs of students and workers over a lifetime of learning and work, including those looking to update their qualifications or change careers.
Affordability - where students aren’t saddled with huge debts to get a university education.

Accessibility - where there are enough university places to meet the nation’s future skills needs. Where Australians who get the marks and want to study can earn a spot. And where vocational education and universities are cohesive, adaptable, equally valued and supported.

As the children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren of these heroes, we will never forget their lives and their deeds. And we will never stop working to build an Australia worthy of their sacrifice.

39,000 gave their life. Another 30,000 were made prisoner.

The war changed people – and it changed Australia.

Those who survived were determined to build a better world out of the ashes.

Almost a million people served the nation. They fought in every corner of the globe – from continental Europe, to North Africa, to Asia + the Pacific.

They faced the biggest military threat in the nation’s modern history, + with remarkable bravery, they pushed it back.

We need to build a strong economy with good jobs, including in our regions. But we can’t separate Australia’s economic future from the protection of our environment.
 
Let’s do both.
Julia Gillard ended Workchoices with the Fair Work Act - and legislated for a price on carbon.
Kevin Rudd saved 200,000 jobs during the GFC - and legislated a renewable energy target.
Paul Keating introduced superannuation and the Working Nation jobs program - and established the National Reserve System to protect threatened habitats.
Bob Hawke reformed the economy and set up decades of employment growth - and saved the Franklin River.
Gough Whitlam created tens of thousands of jobs in suburbs and regions with high unemployment - and made the Great Barrier Reef a National Park.

Labor has always understood that supporting jobs and the environment aren’t mutually exclusive. We can and should do both.

12. Connection matters. Our families and friends, our sporting teams, our colleagues, the groups we’re part of all make our lives richer. We need to make the space in our lives for community.
11. International cooperation is vital to solving our most stubborn problems. Trust, transparency, an effective aid program, and scientific cooperation between nations benefit us all.
10. Clean air is good. Blue skies and stars in the night are beautiful. We need to generate more clean energy and improve vehicle emission standards.
9. We can house rough sleepers if we want to. We just need the political will to do it.

8. Teaching is hard work. Kids like school + miss it, despite what they say. School is not babysitting for working parents – teaching is a profession which helps our children grow. (But maybe school should start later in the day for teens. They don’t think well in the morning!)

Too many of these jobs are undervalued and underpaid. Technology has transformed the way many people can work and live our lives. Lots of jobs can be done effectively remotely – at least part of the time. We also have to build our capacity as a nation to make things.

7. Some work will and should change. The people who do some of the most important work are not the highest paid. Our economy relies on essential workers, from shop assistants, to delivery drivers, to cleaners. It relies on nurses, aged care workers, and early educators.
If we want to support demand in the economy, we need to make sure low income earners get the most help, because they will spend on essentials.

6. No one can live on $40 a day. Economic inequality + poverty are bad for everyone. People who can’t pay the bills or buy food will keep working, even if they're sick. A secure job or strong social safety net protects the sick worker, but also protects the rest of the community.

5. We need to invest in science + medical research – and we need to value the knowledge it provides us. Facts matter. The truth matters. Listen to experts. That also means strengthening + reducing inequalities in our world class education system, including schools, TAFEs, + unis.

4. Our democracy still allows for bipartisanship. Political parties can come together for the common good. We should do it more often. And we should thank our public servants who swing into action in such crises, and the experts who guide them.
In an emergency, that care is equally available to everyone. A two tier health system would allow the virus to spread more freely – which is what’s happening in some other countries.

3. Thank God for Medicare. A universal health system saves lives. User pays health systems cost lives. We have a great public health system, with some of the best medical and support staff anywhere in the world.
People need a secure job and a roof over their head. We need to work together with good faith to deliver full employment.

2. We can work together to promote a strong economy which delivers security and stability. Unions and employers can be pragmatic and cooperate to protect and grow jobs. We need to harness this for Australia to have a prosperous future.
Some have behaved badly in the toilet paper aisle, and too many have gone to the beach; but many, many more have reached out and offered to help neighbours. We are keen to care for each other.

1. Australians are prepared to make sacrifices for one another if we feel like we are all in something together. We tell ourselves that we are larrikin rule breakers, but very few have ignored social distancing rules.

But with the scale of Australia’s challenges, both to our health and our economy, it’s unlikely that society will just ‘snap back’ to how it was before. Some things will change forever.
 
So what have we learned so far in this crisis?

Thread 👇

You can be a progressive and love your country: I certainly do.
You can be proud of your citizenship and dedicated to progress. You can cherish this nation and want to make it better.
To love your country is not to assume that it’s perfect. Patriotism is not above self-reflection and self-improvement.
To love your country is not to assume it’s better than others. Patriots don’t need to feel superior to feel proud.
Patriotism is the knowledge that we’re not alone in this life; that our neighbours are there to share our struggles; that we have 25 million people in our corner when we need it.
Patriotism, like mateship, is about solidarity. It’s about what we owe each other as citizens.
It’s an elegant expression of what it  takes to be a good citizen – of the rights we hold and the responsibilities we owe.
